none: Examination of Junior Class, Second Section in English signed by Louis L. McInnis, February 11, 1879
Examination of Junior Class, Second Section in English signed by Louis L. McInnis, February 11, 1879
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 3 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[1879, Feb. 11]

STATE
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL
COLLEGE OF TEXAS
COLLEGE STATION BRAZOS COUNTY
M. Strickland Lith. Galv.

187

Examination of Junior Class
Second section in English –
Text book, Fowler’s English Grammar
From the beginning to Chap. XI Page
174. Derivation –
February – 11th 1879–
Questions – with valuation –

I Give the three opinions in with re-
spect to the origin of language. 6.

II. Name the families of the Indo-
European stock of languages,
and from which does the Eng-
lish come? 10

III What is a dialect? 5

IV What are the principal elements,
which enter into the composition
of the English Language, 6.

V What are the phonetic elements

**My Transcription of the Examination Paper** Alright, I'm diving into this image. My goal is to capture the essence of this handwritten examination paper. First, I need to break down the image visually. There's a prominent letterhead, and I'm going to start there. * I see a handwritten pencil note in the top right, `[1879, Feb. 11]`. That's likely a date or some identifying metadata. * Then, the main letterhead text: `STATE AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS`. It looks like it's split over some banners with the words `COLLEGE STATION` and `BRAZOS COUNTY` at the bottom and a small print: `M. Strickland Lith. Galv.` under the image. This is a bit smaller. * On the right-hand side, I spot `187` in handwritten ink. It looks like it could be a date or page number. * Okay, next comes the main text, also handwritten in ink. * "Examination of Junior Class" * "Second section in English –" * "Text book, Fowler's English Grammar" * "From the beginning to Chap. XI Page" * "174. Derivation –" * "February – 11th 1879–" * "Questions – with valuation –" * "I Give the three opinions in with re-" * "spect to the origin of language. 6." * "II. Name the families of the Indo-" * "European stock of languages," * "and from which does the Eng-" * "lish come? 10" * "III What is a dialect? 5" * "IV What are the principal elements," * "which enter into the composition" * "of the English Language, 6." * "V What are the phonetic elements" I'm making a mental note that the word "in" is inserted above "with" in the first question, so I will have to reflect that as well. The valuations (6, 10, 5, 6) look to be at the end of the question lines. Now, let's start the actual transcription. I'll preserve the line breaks. I'll try to follow visual hierarchy when formatting the header and keep the handwriting details. My plan is to start with the top pencil date, then the header text, date fragment, and then the exam questions. I will use the approved HTML tags for formatting. Here's the final output:

[1879, Feb. 11]

STATE
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL
COLLEGE OF TEXAS
COLLEGE STATION BRAZOS COUNTY
M. Strickland Lith. Galv.

187

Examination of Junior Class

Second section in English –

Text book, Fowler's English Grammar

From the beginning to Chap. XI Page

174. Derivation –

February – 11th 1879–

Questions – with valuation –

I Give the three opinions in with re- 6.

spect to the origin of language.

II. Name the families of the Indo- 10

European stock of languages,

and from which does the Eng-

lish come?

III What is a dialect? 5

IV What are the principal elements, 6.

which enter into the composition

of the English Language,

V What are the phonetic elements

the English language? the Consonantal 27
sounds? the vocal sounds? 9

VI. Mention the continuous & the explosive
elements, the labials, the dentals, the
gutturals, the nasals_ 10

VII. Define primitive, simple, derivative
& compound words_ 4

VIII. Compose a sentence in which there
shall be surd elements & sonant
elements & point them out. 10

IX "In science reason is guide"
write this phonetically_ 10

X Mention the four defects of the
English alphabet_ 8

XI Name & define the parts of speech
mention the classes of adjectives, 12

XII_ What is conjugation? Conjugate
the verb "buy" & give the synopsis in
the passive voice _ Does this
verb belong to the strong or to
the weak conjugation_ 10

100

Louis L. McInnis _
adj. Prof_ Anc. Langs & Eng.
State A & m. College of Texas_

**Alright, let's break down this handwritten document. My analysis is as follows:** I'm looking at what seems to be a late 19th or early 20th-century exam or assignment. The content screams grammar/linguistics, and the handwriting style supports the historical timeframe. The structure is clear: questions numbered VI through XII, each with assigned scores in the right margin. First, I start line by line: * `

the English language? the Consonantal 27
sounds? the vocal sounds? 9

` Okay, we have what looks like part of a previous question, probably the tail end of V. There's an upper-right number, "27," which is small and likely a page number or total. The next line has "sounds" and a "9" on the right. Next, I look at the numbered questions: * `

VI. Mention the continuous & the explosive
elements, the labials, the dentals, the
gutturals, the nasals_ 10

` That's VI, straightforward enough. * `

VII. Define primitive, simple, derivative
& compound words_ 4

` VII follows. * `

VIII. Compose a sentence in which there
shall be surd elements & sonant
elements & point them out. 10

` Now comes VIII, the word "surd" is the old school term for a voiceless consonant, and "sonant" means voiced. Good. * `

IX "In science reason is guide"
write this phonetically_ 10

` Next is IX, with that famous quote, "In science reason is guide," and a phonetic transcription exercise. * `

X Mention the four defects of the
English alphabet_ 8

` Then X. * `

XI Name & define the parts of speech
mention the classes of adjectives, 12

` Moving onto XI with a reminder for what adjectives are. * `

XII_ What is conjugation? Conjugate
the verb "buy" & give the synopsis in
the passive voice _ Does this
verb belong to the strong or to
the weak conjugation_ 10

` And finally, XII, dealing with verb conjugation, with the verb "buy". Now, I will note: `

100

` Then at the end, the total: 100. The signature block looks like this: `

Louis L. McInnis _
adj. Prof_ Anc. Langs & Eng.
State A & m. College of Texas_

` "McInnis" appears to be the name. The "adj" likely stands for "adjunct" professor, and "Anc. Langs & Eng." indicates Ancient Languages and English. The college is "State A & m. College of Texas". I think I have a solid transcription. Time to get this into HTML format for the IIIF presentation, according to the given instructions.
